A: SHOW GRANTS OF ROLE shows who as been granted (Correct)
B: SHOW GRANTS TO ROLE show privileges granted

A: SHOW GRANTS OF ROLE this option shows which users and roles have access to a role,
while,
B: SHOW GRANTS TO ROLE this option only shows which roles have access to a role, is doesn't specify the user.

Answer is B

ROLE role_name

MY_ROLE doesn't have access to users and roles. It is the other way round - Users and roles were given access to MY_ROLE so SHOW GRANTS OF ROLE MY_ROLE.

Answer is A. 
SHOW OF ROLE and SHOW TO ROLE has different outputs.

It could A or B

Syntax
SHOW GRANTS

SHOW GRANTS ON ACCOUNT

SHOW GRANTS ON <object_type> <object_name>

SHOW GRANTS TO { ROLE <role_name> | USER <user_name> | SHARE <share_name> }

SHOW GRANTS OF ROLE <role_name>

SHOW GRANTS OF SHARE <share_name>

SHOW FUTURE GRANTS IN SCHEMA { <schema_name> }

SHOW FUTURE GRANTS IN DATABASE { <database_name> }

SHOW FUTURE GRANTS TO ROLE <role_name>

https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/sql/show-grants.html

Selected Answer: A
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/sql/show-grants.html

questions.question_text:
A user created a transient table and made several changes to it over the course of several days. Three days after the table was created, the user would like to go back to the first version of the table.

How can this be accomplished?

choices.B: The transient table version cannot be retrieved after 24 hours.
choices.A: Use Time Travel, as long as DATA_RETENTION_TIME_IN_DAYS was set to at least 3 days.
choices.C: Contact Snowflake Support to have the data retrieved from Fail-safe storage.
choices.D: Use the FAIL_SAFE parameter for Time Travel to retrieve the data from Fail-safe storage.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/tables-temp-transient

Selected Answer: A
If the snowflake edition is Enterprise and can go up-to to 90 days. If time travel set to 90 days for Transient tables.

Selected Answer: B
Correct
A use time travel https://community.snowflake.com/s/article/Time-Travel-Inherited-DATA-RETENTION-TIME-IN-DAYS-Parameter-Retained-in-Transient-Tables

Selected Answer: B
correct answer

Selected Answer: B
For transient table the time travel is from 0 to 1 days.

Selected Answer: B
Correct Answer

choices.E: Limit user access to the warehouse so fewer queries are run against it.
choices.D: Migrate some queries to a new warehouse to reduce load.
choices.C: Stop and start the warehouse to clear the queued queries.
choices.B: Scale up the warehouse size to allow queries to execute faster.
choices.A: Use multi-clustered warehousing to scale out warehouse capacity.

questions.question_text:
When reviewing the load for a warehouse using the load monitoring chart, the chart indicates that a high volume of queries is always queuing in the warehouse.

According to recommended best practice, what should be done to reduce the queue volume? (Choose two.)

comments.content:
If the running query load is high or there’s queuing, consider
- starting a separate warehouse and moving queued queries to that warehouse. - Alternatively, if you are using multi-cluster warehouses, you could change your multi-cluster settings to add additional clusters to handle higher concurrency going forward.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
This is per Snowflake documentation:
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/warehouses-load-monitoring.html#slow-query-performance

Selected Answer: AD
consider starting a separate warehouse and moving queued queries to that warehouse.
You are trying to solve for concurrency, so either scale out or add new warehouses
Correct answer:AB

Selected Answer: AB
A&B r correct

Selected Answer: AD
Correct

Selected Answer: AB
if queries execute faster, there will be lesser queries in the queue. moving to another virtual warehouse may be a temporary fix, but when it's a persistent problem then you should first scale out your virtual warehouse. If scaling out does not fully address the issue, you should consider scaling up as well

Selected Answer: AD
If the running query load is high or there’s queuing, consider starting a separate warehouse and moving queued queries to that warehouse. Alternatively, if you are using multi-cluster warehouses, you could change your multi-cluster settings to add additional clusters to handle higher concurrency going forward.

Selected Answer: AD
Tricky question as scaling up (B) could potentially also help. However, I think it's A/D because the question is about loading data and, thus, concurrency, not complex queries.

AB, not AD, the key word here is 'always' which indicates the action needed is for following computes but not necessarily current running queries. moving queued queries to new warehouse is temp solution. scale up and scale out is the permanent solution. https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/warehouses-load-monitoring.html#slow-query-performance

Selected Answer: AD
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/warehouses-load-monitoring.html#slow-query-performance

Selected Answer: AD
correct answer
AD for sure

Selected Answer: AD
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/warehouses-load-monitoring.html#slow-query-performance

AB: If the running query load is high or there’s queuing, consider starting a separate warehouse and moving queued queries to that warehouse. Alternatively, if you are using multi-cluster warehouses, you could change your multi-cluster settings to add additional clusters to handle higher concurrency going forward.

comments.content: if queries execute faster, there will be lesser queries in the queue. moving to another virtual warehouse may be a temporary fix, but when it's a persistent problem then you should first scale out your virtual warehouse. If scaling out does not fully address the issue, you should consider scaling up as well

discussion.content: This is interesting. A,B,D all 3 are correct according to https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/warehouses-load-monitoring.html#slow-query-performance

Selected Answer: AB
https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/warehouses-load-monitoring.html#slow-query-performance

comments.content:
Hi @Tapasgup007
from: https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/warehouses-load-monitoring.html#slow-query-performance
If the running query load is high or there’s queuing, consider starting a separate warehouse and moving queued queries to that warehouse. Alternatively, if you are using multi-cluster warehouses, you could change your multi-cluster settings to add additional clusters to handle higher concurrency going forward.

To Increse the size of warehouse is the right answer if:
If the running query load is low and query performance is slow, you could resize the warehouse to provide more compute resources. You would need to restart the query once all the new resources were fully provisioned to take advantage of the added resources

But the question said that we have " high volume of queries". So the right answers are A,D
